events.summary: Leoš Janáček entered the world in Hukvaldy with a grand entrance on 3 July, 1854, proving from the start that he was destined to create music that would echo across centuries, even if his early life was filled with the usual sibling squabbling.

In a romantic twist befitting an opera, Janáček tied the knot with his music pupil Zdenka Schulzová on 13 July, 1881, perhaps thinking it would inspire more love songs - spoiler alert: it did, but not without drama!

Janáček took the helm as the director of the Brno organ school in 1881, proving that he wasn't just a composer but also a big cheese in the educational world - move over, teachers, there’s a new maestro in town!
After much anticipation, his opera Jenůfa hit the stage in 1904. Despite earlier rejections, this time it made waves, proving that good things come to those who wait... and maybe whine a little.
Finally, in a triumphant moment, a revised edition of Jenůfa was accepted in 1916 at the National Theatre in Prague, giving Janáček the green light to waltz onto the global opera scene with flair!
In 1920, Janáček hung up his hat as director of the Brno Conservatory, probably to focus on composing directly, as well as taking a well-deserved break from grading music papers!
In 1925, he was awarded the first honorary doctorate by Masaryk University, solidifying his status as a musical genius while also providing him a reason to wear a fancy hat at ceremonies.
Janáček composed his magnificent Sinfonietta in 1926, a work that quickly became the belle of the ball in orchestral music; who knew a few notes could create such a stir?
Janáček made a splash in London, and it was as if his music said, 'Greetings from Moravia!' with a windy sextet and a string quartet that had everyone tapping their toes and asking, 'What’s next?'
The world finally got to hear Janáček's Concertino, and the musical chatter was all about how it was a delightful mix of instruments, just like a potluck dinner with surprisingly good results!
Janáček premiered his Capriccio, a piece so unusual that one might think it was written for an orchestra of circus performers—minus the elephants, of course!
The Sinfonietta saw its first performances in New York and Berlin, making Janáček an international sensation, though he still wondered if they served good coffee at intermission!
Janáček dove into composing his 'Intimate Letters', a string quartet that doubled as a love letter—he must have really liked string instruments!
While on a seemingly innocent excursion to Štramberk with Kamila, Janáček caught a chill. One could say that he took the 'chill' part a bit too seriously!
Janáček took his final bow in Ostrava, and one could almost hear his music echoing behind him as he departed the stage of life—perhaps a dramatic exit was his way of saying 'Stay tuned!'

Janáček took a plunge into the folk music world, collecting songs like a kid collecting candy. He became quite the anthropologist, gathering everything from Lachian melodies to sultry Slovakian tunes, showcasing a talent for transcribing speech intonations that would put even the best linguists to shame.

In Brno, Janáček decided it was time to share his genius—like a chef excited to share a secret recipe. He educated a bevy of eager musicians, though it turns out many didn't bother following his unique sound, perhaps preferring to cook up their own!

events.event: Becoming President of the Working Committee for Czech National Folksong
events.summary: In a bold power move, Janáček assumed the presidency of the folksong committee, making him the big cheese in the world of Czech melodies. It was kind of like becoming the CEO of the Czech music industry with a flair for the dramatic and authentic.

When Janáček acquired an Edison phonograph, he transformed into a true tech enthusiast of his time. He started recording folk songs, becoming one of the coolest ethnographers around and perhaps the first to say, 'Hey, let me just hit record on that catchy tune!'

Janáček dove into the world of music theory, publishing various works that might resemble a scholarly version of 'how to be a musical genius.' His writings became a treasure trove of wisdom, potentially helping others avoid hitting wrong notes in life and music!

With the debut of 'Jenůfa', Janáček burst onto the opera scene like a star should. The combination of dramatic music and themes made audiences gasp—and his peers wonder how he pulled it off without a wand!

Though not a musical hoarder, Janáček contributed a few gems to the chamber music scene that have stood the test of time. His string quartets remain classics, proving that sometimes less is indeed more (unless you're talking about cookies, then more is more!).

As a budding composer, Janáček had his first public performance, likely surprising everyone by not just playing the piano, but doing so with the flair of a man who had just discovered the joy of creative expression – and coffee!

In a moment that can be described as both brave and remarkably optimistic, Janáček co-founded the Czech Philharmonic, proving that even in music, if you build it, they might just come – with instruments!

Finally, his patience paid off when his opera 'Jenůfa' premiered. It was a hit, leaving audiences wondering if it was the music or just Janáček's charm that captivated them – spoiler alert: it was both!

Janáček's fame spread internationally, as he became a darling of the music world, securing invitations from Europe’s finest. They say he wasn’t just invited for his music; his wit and convivial nature were hard to resist as well!

As he reached the twilight of his career, Janáček produced his last major work, showing that he could still whip up musical masterpieces faster than a chef can whip up a soufflé – but with arguably more emotional depth!

compositions.title: Řikadla pro komorní sbor a 10 nástrojů
